item.title: 5 Reasons Why So Many People Believe Feminism Hates Men and Why They‚Äôre Not True
item.description:
‚ÄúThe feminist agenda is not about equal rights for women. It is about a socialist, anti-family political movement that encourages women to leave their husbands, kill their children, practice witchcraft, destroy capitalism, and become lesbians.‚Äù

Pat Robertson famously said this in the 90s, and the sentiment still rings as true in the ears of many today. ¬†It‚Äôs an understatement to say that¬†feminism has a bad rap.

Feminism doesn‚Äôt hate men.

So why do so many people think feminism = man-hating? Let‚Äôs look at a few explanations for this fallacy.

item.title: You Soup: understanding diversity and the intersections of identity
item.description:
In doing the work I do, I often find myself struggling to help people make sense of the two extremes of identity: on one side we have the idea that people in a group are all the same (stereotypes); while the other side supports this idea that everyone is absolutely unique (snowflakes).

I find myself saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not the same, but we‚Äôre also not that different,‚Äù to the furrowing of brows, so I wanted to take a moment here to talk about the relationship of individual identity and social group memberships, as well as introduce a new graphic concept.

item.title: How To Avoid Being a Stereotype
item.description:
You want to be seen as an individual, right? ¬†Of course you do. ¬†But it‚Äôs bordering on impossible to avoid perpetuating at least some of the stereotypes attached to the various aspects of your identity. ¬†There are just too many of them!

Well, that‚Äôs where I can help. ¬†Consider this a ‚ÄúHow to be [X], without being a stereotypical [X]‚Äù guide. ¬†I‚Äôm hitting a variety of major identities, but feel free to request addendums to the guide in the comments below, on Facebook, or on Twitter.

Also, if you‚Äôre more prone to spot-reading than reading-reading, I strongly encourage you to at least read the last section before you formulate your reaction to this article.

Without further ado, in alphabetical order‚Ä¶

item.title: 5 Reasons My Approach to Social Justice Work is Better than Yours
item.description:
The way I approach social justice and ally work on this site and¬†in my show has a distinct flavor. ¬†Some would call it sweet, but I think ginger is a bit spicy.

I don‚Äôt often do things by accident, and in this case it is very _on purpose. ¬†_My flavor is even so noticeable that if you‚Äôve seen a lot of what I‚Äôve created here, you‚Äôre likely taken aback by the headline of this article. ¬†Well, that actually leads me into my first point.

item.title: Why Your Intentions Don't Really Matter, but Outcomes Do
item.description:
I‚Äôve created a few¬†graphics¬†about when it‚Äôs okay to say ‚Äúgay‚Äù¬†and the one argument that keeps coming up goes something like ‚ÄúHow can you regulate language? What‚Äôs offensive to one person is not to another. ¬†What matters is your intentions.‚Äù

To that, the first and most important thing I have to say is this: Your intentions don‚Äôt matter as much as the effect of your actions.

I will elaborate on my response to that question more in a bit, but first I want to pose another question, and posit an answer.
